source.name: Infant Mortality Rate by Race and Hispanic Origin per Year Chart
source.description:
- Racial disparities are observed in the rate of infant mortality.

- In 2009, the rate of infant death for Black/African American infants (14.4) was two times higher than the comparable rate for white infants (6.9).  Unfortunately, this finding is typical of both Oklahoma and the US.  On average, Black/African American infants have IMRs 2 to 2.5 times higher than white infants.  This gap has been an enduring health disparity for the state and nation.

- Hispanics have IMRs that are consistently better than all other racial or ethnic groups.
